name: ENTITY
description: The root node

feature_types.explain: In extension of
Has a part
Is part of
Experienced as
Prototype
Source
Associated with

name: ABSTRACT
description: Something that doesn't exist physically, nor is an event

name: REAL
description: A real object or event.

name: INDIVIDUAL
description: An entity that occurs as a singular or is not compositional.

name: IDEAL
description: An abstract entity that represents a desired state. For example, 'order' in 'law and order'

name: PROPOSITIONAL
description: A statement or an abstract component of speech- such as sentence

name: QUANTITY
description: An entity that can be either measured, is numerical or is related to measurement

name: IRREAL
description: An entity that doesn't exist in the world/imaginary/mythological

name: QUALITY
description: An entity relating to an observed quality such as kindness

name: PHYSICAL
description: A physical object

feature_types.explain: The general shape of an object (mostly geometrical shapes, but exceptions may exist
The size of an object (use vehicles or buildings for comparison (ex: elephant-> big-> truck sized)
The common color of an object
The material property (steel, paper, fibers, biological tissue, etc)
The texture of an object (smooth, rough, etc)
The common odor associated with object
The common taste associated with object
The common location of an object
Strength of the object
The physical state of an object (gas, liquid, solid...)

name: SENTIENT
description: A human type with specific traits and goals.

feature_types.explain: The distinctive trait of a particular sentient. For example, lawyers are commonly quick-thinking, etc
The goal of a sentient. For example, lawyers have the goal to win cases for clients.

name: NATURAL
description: A naturally occuring entity (not created/developed by human)

name: SOCIAL
description: An entity created by humans or arising from society.

feature_types.explain: Either what an object is used for, or what a person/sentient does
The prerequisites or required tools or objects to function
The manner in which a SOCIAL entity is processed/created/comes to be

name: STATIONARY
description: A physical entity that does not move.

name: LIVING
description: A biologically living entity.

feature_types.explain: The source of a living object- example mammals are mainly through 'live births'
Where the living entity is commonly found
What the living entity is composed of/body form
The age of a living entity

name: NONLIVING
description: A non-living entity.

name: STATIONARY
description: Describes things that are normally immobile, attached to the earth and moved only at great effort.

name: NONSTATIONARY
description: Describes things that are able to move or be moved.

name: SELFMOVING
description: Describes things that are normally in motion or designed for motion, in some cases with no apparent initial source.

name: NONSELFMOVING
description: Describes things that are normally immobile but can be moved with slight effort.

name: COLLECTIVE
description: Describes a group of entities as a whole.

name: MASS
description: Even the smallest amount is of the same material nature as the collective term (a drop of water is still water), and whose members are referred to only in terms of measurable units.

name: SET
description: Each member of the set is the same kind as every other member.

name: STRUCTURE

feature_types.example: management,staff
feature_types.explain: describes the roles inside the structure

feature_types.example: managers are in charge of managing staff
feature_types.explain: explains the duty and responsibility of the role

description: Each member is of the same kind type as every other member; members have specified relations with one another.

name: TEMPORAL
description: There is a time aspect to the entity in question.

name: RELATIONAL

feature_types.example: Times Square
feature_types.explain: describes where it occured.

feature_types.example: 2100 hours
feature_types.explain: describes when it happened.

feature_types.example: The man fell down because he tripped on a rock
feature_types.explain: describes the cause of the event

feature_types.example: The forest fires were caused by dense underbrush
feature_types.explain: describes what allowed an event to happen

feature_types.example: Thus 1600 people perished in the fires
feature_types.explain: describes the consequences of the event

feature_types.example: Subsequently more efforts were channeled into raising awareness for forest fires
feature_types.explain: describes subsequent events following the inital event

description: Verbs are attached here.

name: NONRELATIONAL
description: Temporal nouns (nouns that relate to time i.e, seasons) go here.

name: STATIVE

feature_types.example: Times Square

feature_types.example: Thus 1600 people perished in the fires
feature_types.explain: describes the consequences of the event

feature_types.example: Subsequently more efforts were channeled into raising awareness for forest fires
feature_types.explain: describes subsequent events following the inital event
